dt: {bc}to stay in place in expectation of {bc}{sx|await||}

dt.t: {wi}waited{/wi} the result of the advertisement
{wi}wait{/wi} your turn

dt: {bc}to serve food and drinks to the people sitting at {bc}to act as a {d_link|server|server} for

dt.t: {wi}wait{/wi} tables

dt: {bc}to remain stationary in readiness or expectation

dt.t: {wi}wait{/wi} for a train

dt: {bc}to pause for another to catch up

dt.t: just {wi}waiting{/wi} to see his rival lose
{wi}waiting{/wi} for a chance to strike

dt: usually used in such phrases as {it}wait on tables{/it} or {it}wait on table{/it}

dt.t: slippers {wi}waiting{/wi} by the bed
the chores can {wi}wait{/wi}

dt: used to preface an interjected question, correction, etc.

dt.t: "{wi}Wait{/wi}, Mom. {wi}Wait{/wi}. What did you say?" I said. "He left you what?"
So {wi}wait{/wi}, what's so bad about wanting to eat right?

pt: American dialectologists have evidence showing {it}wait on{/it} (sense 3) to be more a Southern than a Northern form in speech. Handbook writers universally denigrate {it}wait on{/it} and prescribe {it}wait for{/it} in writing. Our evidence from printed sources does not show a regional preference; it does show that the handbooks' advice is not based on current usage.

pt.t: settlement of the big problems still {it}waited on{/it} Russia
I couldn't make out … whether Harper was {it}waiting on{/it} me for approval
the staggering bill that {it}waited on{/it} them at the white commissary downtown

pt: One reason for the continuing use of {it}wait on{/it} may lie in its being able to suggest protracted or irritating waits better than {it}wait for{/it}.

pt.t: for two days I've been {it}waiting on{/it} weather
the boredom of black Africans sitting there, {it}waiting on{/it} the whims of a colonial bureaucracy
doesn't care to sit around {it}waiting on{/it} a House that's virtually paralyzed

pt: {it}Wait on{/it} is less common than {it}wait for{/it}, but if it seems natural, there is no reason to avoid it.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}waiter, guaiter{/it} to watch over, await, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German {it}wahta{/it} watch, Old English {it}wæccan{/it} to watch {ma}{mat|wake|}{/ma}
shortdef: to stay in place in expectation of : await
to serve food and drinks to the people sitting at : to act as a server for

dt: used chiefly in the expression {it}lie in wait{/it}
{bc}a state or attitude of watchfulness and expectancy

dt.t: anchored in {wi}wait{/wi} for early morning fishing

dt: {bc}one of a band of public musicians in England employed to play for processions or public entertainments
{bc}one of a group who serenade for gratuities especially at the Christmas season
{bc}a piece of music by such a group

dt.t: a long {wi}wait{/wi} in line

et: Middle English {it}waite{/it} watchman, observation, from Anglo-French, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German {it}wahta{/it} watch
shortdef: a hidden or concealed position —used chiefly in the expression lie in wait
a state or attitude of watchfulness and expectancy
one of a band of public musicians in England employed to play for processions or public entertainments
to put on a waiting list

dt.t: {it}wait{/it} the storm {it}out{/it}

dt: used to tell someone to stop and wait briefly

dt.t: {it}Wait a minute{/it}. I need to tie my shoe.
If you will just {it}wait a second{/it}, I can explain what happened.

dt: used to interrupt someone or something because one has noticed, thought of, or remembered something

dt.t: {it}Wait a second{/it}—that's not what she said.
{it}Wait a minute{/it}. I just remembered where I put the keys.

shortdef: —used to tell someone to stop and wait briefly
—used to interrupt someone or something because one has noticed, thought of, or remembered something

dt: {bc}to serve food or drinks as a waiter or waitress

dt.t: He {it}waited at table{/it} for two years.

shortdef: to serve food or drinks as a waiter or waitress

dt: used to emphasize that the following statement is foolish, surprising, funny, etc.

dt.t: He says he was fired because—{it}wait for it{/it}—he refused to compromise his principles.

shortdef: —used to emphasize that the following statement is foolish, surprising, funny, etc.

dt: {bc}to stay at home and wait for someone or something to arrive

dt.t: I can't go out. I've got to {it}wait in{/it} for a delivery.

shortdef: to stay at home and wait for someone or something to arrive

stems: wait on someone hand and foot

dt: {bc}to provide everything that someone needs or wants {bc}to act as a servant to (someone)

dt.t: I can't stand the way they {it}wait on her hand and foot{/it}!
She {it}waited on her children hand and foot{/it}.

shortdef: to provide everything that someone needs or wants : to act as a servant to (someone)

dt: {bc}to not do something until it is one's turn

dt.t: You will have to {it}wait your turn{/it}.

shortdef: to not do something until it is one's turn
